tl;drA worth-while entry in the Kart Racer genre that is entirely over-looked because it's a Floppy Ear title! Fun for all ages and a Buy for Kart Racing enthusiasts.full review.Teddy Floppy Ear - The Race is a cute, little Kart Racer that has more going on than you can shake a stick at.  It has several racing modes, several kart performance upgrades, plenty of unlockables from cars to characters, several difficulty levels to accomodate racers of all skill-levels and some beautiful and cartoony courses with enough variety to keep it interesting.  Best of all, it has a surprisingly solid sense of speed, which is core to any good racing game.  It's unfortunate that this game doesn't get a fair chance inspite of it's lineage; from the perspective of a single-player Kart Racer, it's pretty darn good.  There are, however, some minor problems:First: the wonky controls. They are soft and slippery.  They can almost feel broken when you first start playing.  But... once you adapt to the steering mechanics and adjust your driving style, you will find yourself speeding around corners and passing your competitors with ease and glee. The learning curve for me was about 45-minutes of race-time. Second: The weird music.And as far as the music goes, it's weird and a total mismatch for what is happening on-screen. Turn it off in the Settings and play your own up-tempo music of choice.  I played EDM and Trance for this game and it kicked up the atmosphere to eleven.Once you disable the weirdly mismatched music and spend some time learning how to control your racer... it becomes really fun!It's definitely no Sonic Racer, but, it's certainly better and more fun than, the albeit more polished, F1 Race All-stars.  Of all the Kart Racers on Steam, it's a worth-while one. At full price (4,99 at the time of this review), I would recommend this for Kart Racing enthusiasts. However, if you enjoy Kart Racing and are the type of gamer who is willing to put a bit of time into learning how to steer your kart, then this is an easy Buy, especially if you get it on sale. pros.+ Cute pseudo-paper-cutout graphics style+ Well-designed tracks, including shortcuts+ Beautifully cartoony tracks+ Fun and responsive power-ups and attacks+ Day and night tracks+ Good AI competitors+ Solid sense of speed+ Split-screen, local multiplayer (I didn't test this)+ Many unlockables (tracks, cars, characters, etc)+ Kart performance upgrades (tires, exhaust, paint jobs, etc)+ Full 1080P Support+ Full Controller Supportcons.- Music is just terrible  (turn it off and play your own)- Kart controls are sloppy, but fun once you adapt- No online multiplayer support- Limited graphics settingsThis game is appropriate for all ages and skill-levels.Please hit the like button if you found this review at all helpful.  Thanks :D

												Cute small cart racer for beginners.There are 6 well-designed tracks (some have a night mode, most have a shortcut), some racing modes (single race with 4 difficulties, time trial, cone collecting, and two different tournament modes, respectively), no performance tuning, street features such as speedup arrows, a slow sand patch and a wet patch that wets your tires so that your next turn is harder to control. There are also a bunch of power-ups that speed you up or the others down (no weapons more violent than a box of thumbtacks, though). There's no story. All in all it's fairly varied.You get two keyboard setups and you can also use one Xbox controller, which unfortunately is also all you get for split-screen. I'm calling this a beginners game because the AI and the difficulty of the challenges are no match for more experienced players once you've gotten the hang of the game (do have a look at the help before you start).  Physics are a bit strange in that you get rubber on the road long before you can hear a tire squeal, and I turned the music off after a while, but all in all it handles predictably enough for cart game physics.I'm approximately halfway through the game, and to me it feels casual and I'm happy I didn't spend any money on it. But given the variety of race modes and tracks, it'd be a good game for a budding racing gamer - and that's precisely who it's aimed at. Recommended.

												Teddy Floppy Ear - The Race is a kart racing game in the universe of Teddy Floppy Ear. If you don't know Teddy Floppy Ear, you're like me, because I've never heard something of that until I bought this game, but Teddy Floppy Ear seems to be a thing in Poland. However, the whole story of the game is really simple. There are some animals on a farm and they have the great idea to do some kart racing. But who cares about the story in a racing game?You can choose between 5 different racing modes in the game. In the "Single Race" mode you do a standard racing game against opponents. In "Time Attack" you drive against the time. In "Collectors Slalom" you have to collect stars. In "Racing Season" you do a season, in "Floppy Cup" you drive a cup. Except in "Time Attack" and "Collectors Slalom" you can choose the difficulty level.And here's the first problem of the game: In all the different racing modes there are just 5 tracks. The 5 tracks are available in a day and night mode, but that don't change the fact that there are just 5 tracks and it's get really boring fast. And if that were not enough, you always have to do 3 rounds on every track to end the race, what really sucks when you do a cup or a season.What also really sucks is the sound of the game. There are just a few soundtracks and they repeat themselves over and over again. And the graphics is, hmmm, nothing really special, while the gameplay is slippery and the controls are wonky, but you get used to it if you play some time.But there are also some good facts. The characters and cars are made cute, so this game is kid friendly. You can also read some history facts about the cars. And while racing, in the most modes you can collect boosters and power ups, this makes the race a little more interesting.All in one, this game is definitely not a big title in the racing game genre. You will have some fun for a few hours and then you will never play it again. But if you involve the fact that this is a low price game made by a little developer team, it's okay to buy it. You can also get all achievements if you have the endurance to play this game for about 5 hours.Summary+day and night tracks+offline multiplayer+cute characters+historical cars+achievement progress+unlockables-just 5 racing tracks-tracks getting boring fast-wonky controller and gameplay-no online multiplayer-standard graphics-10 trading cards to get steam badge

												I have been playing video games for almost the full time I have been alive, owned more consoles than years I have been alive, and invested more time into gaming in general than any other activity in my life.With all this noted, I can safely say that Teddy Floopy Ear - The Race is the best game I have ever played.The character development in this game is truly outstanding, and the story is both inspiring and breathtaking at times, you will feel every emotion you have even known plus more; joy, sadness, anger, regret, fear, shock, surprise, disgust and true love. Decisions have consequences and you need to take your time as well as make quick decisions. After a some time you start to feel for your characters and develop various bonds with them; you rely on them for various tasks and you will start to worry taking them into more dangerous areas. Personally, I have never felt such a true bond with any person, living or dead, as I have with the characters in Teddy Floppy Ear - The Race. When you lose a race, you will feel you have personally failed your friends; I have broken down right in front of my PC due to this more times than I can remember.The roleplaying in this game is truly intense, and the replayibility is on another level. Games like the Witcher 3, Skyrim or any other mid-tier game have nothing on the time you will spend in this. As a great man once said, 'Easy to pick up, hard to master'. That man was Teddy Floppy Ear.The over-the-top graphical power of this game may be hard for some players to handle, as the photo realism of the vast green plains, glowing sunsets and life-like characters may scare you with its beauty. Yet, the optimisation is years ahead of its time, and the game will run beautifully on almost any PC. The developers of this game are true geniuses.This is by far the greatest soundtrack in any game ever, the compisitions left me in true awe and the only things even comparable to the sounds that will fill your ears are The Beatles' Sgt. Peppers Lonley Hearts Club Band; Mozart's Symphony No 41, ‘Jupiter’; or the sound of a child being brought into this cruel, cold and unforgiving world. Note that these works sound like fingernails on a blackboard compared to what you will experience in Teddy Floppy Ear - The Race.This is by far the best money I have ever spent. I urge you with all my heart and all my soul to play this masterpiece. 11/10. Game of the millenium.(Note I have over 6,000 hours in this game in offline mode, as I would frequently have to shut myself out from notifications due to the emotional trauma and/or euphoria I experienced so frequently in Teddy Floopy Ear - The Race.)Thank you for reading.

												On the main menu, Teddy Floppy Ear looks like he's ready for a black ops mission.Anyway, Teddy Floppy Ear - The Race is a very watered down version of Mario Kart.While it's fairly obvious this is a children's game, it was still enjoyable and challenging. Then again, I don't play a lot of racing games, so my standards are kinda low when it comes to this genre.Now, the controls are not very fluid, and your turning ability isn't that great. At least when you start. This is probably where a lot of the challenge is going to arise from, because you have to learn how to deal with such clunky turning. But once you have the hang of things, you get sort of better. And once you've stayed first for a while, the rest of the track is a bit of a cruise, assuming you can maintain your performance at a consistent level.As you complete cups and challenges and such, you can earn new gear to add to your cars. I'm not sure if these have any significant impact on your car's performance, or if I'm just getting better at the game. But personally, I do like to think they do something.Much like Mario Kart, you can pick characters and cars to use to race with. Bear in mind that the cars are inspired mostly from Polish motor vehicles from the 1950's to the late 1990's. I would assume this is the case because Teddy Floppy Ear or more accurately, Miś Uszatek was a kids show in Poland around the 1970's time period. Now, I'm not sure if the cars vary in performance since there aren't any 'statistics' for each vehicle, but the Polonez has worked well for me. Characters are (probably) based off the kids show as well, but you can also recall some of them from the other Teddy Floppy Ear games on Steam. Again, the game doesn't tell you anything about the characters except the name and their appearance.The game modes are also fairly standard. Generic races, 1-lap time trials, 1v1 race tourney, collect-the-things-on-the-track races. Nothing overly new, but I think the challenge is emphasised more in the maps the game gives you.While the majority of the maps are manageable with the horrendous steering, track obstacles and other racers, they do give you sharp turns every here and now, and if you're not familiar with the map, it can be a real struggle to get by without crashing into a wall. So speed management and makeshift drifting (i.e. turning while braking or slowing down) is very handy to learn.On the subject of maps, the game also has night levels, which are essentially reskins of the regular levels with a darker backdrop and lights in certain places of the circuit. While this does make the map more challenging especially when you try to use the map shortcuts, it's still sort of easy if you already have an idea about the general layout of its daytime counterpart.Like most racing games these days, there are powerups you can use to give yourself a buff. Apparently, I only found at once I finished the game that the Help section on the main menu literally gives you all the information on controls and powerups. These powerups can be picked up by crashing into them, and override anything you're already currently holding.Surprisingly, since the powerups are not randomised much, you can more or less get any powerup whether you're first, middle or last. You'll also find that there aren't any of those rage-inducing hit-the-first-ranked-player projectiles or homing Red Shells, so I do enjoy not being wrecked by a horde of vengeful AI bots. And there aren't that many powerups to use, but each has its own purpose:Lemonade / Chilli (or Brown?) Sauce: Gives you a boost to 60km/h and lays down a puddle of liquid for other racers to slip on (note that I've never been in a situation where I've slipped in my own traps, so I'm not sure if it's possible). This powerup is useful for speed recovery after a crash.Wellington Boots: Basically just a speed boost. Air Horn / Pigs in Blankets: Produces a shockwave that pushes nearby enemies. Good for early game progress, or when your competition is getting close.Tacks: Sets down a trap for enemies. Probably the least useful powerup.Milk: Make you big, so you can drive faster and crush little tiny baby racers into pancakes. Well, not actual pancakes but you make them flat and slower, similar to the Mega Mushroom powerup in Mario Kart. However, you are more prone to flipping if you steer too sharply.Additionally, the AI is somewhat questionable at times. In most cases, they just drive normally and steer almost as badly as you do. Sometimes they get stuck on walls, and don't seem to recover very well. Usually, this is the case when they're turning and then they crash into a curved wall or they try and use a shortcut but enter in awkwardly. While this is good for you as the player since it makes your job of winning easier, for... reasons, the ranking can get a bit weird at these times. I remember when I was in a 1v1 race with an AI bot, and they got stuck on a wall. Then they were suddenly coming 1st, even though I was practically ahead by half a lap. Soon after, more switching between ranks and then it stabilises back to normal, which at this point the AI bot might have gotten back on track.Lastly, there are achievements and cards. If you can become sufficiently adept at the game, the achievements are easy enough. Sometimes I got achievements for half-completing some of the objectives. As for the cards, they are fairly cheap, and if you're like me, you just let the game run idly to get those last few cards because you finished the game and achievements in under 5 hours.In summary, I'll give Teddy Floppy Ear - The Race a good ol' 6.5 / 10. Very casual stuff, and good practice for things like TrackMania. Could brush up on the AI getting stuck on walls and explanations for whether characters and car enhancements actually do anything.

												Surprisingly competent little cart racer, but clearly not as refined, exciting, or as fun as Mario Kart.  The controls work well (I used a gamepad), but felt a little loose, especially on using the handbreak on turns.  Power ups weren't as iconic or intuitive as Mario Kart, but added an extra element.  Picking from cute little animals makes it a cute game.  However, it just wasn't that interesting or egaging like a Mario Kart game.  I stopped simply because I have games that are more fun to play.  (3/5 stars, also has trading cards).
